hawaiian_text: He keiki ‘u‘uku loa ‘o **a)** Nāmakaokapāo‘o, a he  keiki ikaika loa i kona wā ‘ōpiopio, ‘a‘ohe ona lua  ma kēia mau mokupuni mai Hawai‘i ā Ni‘ihau, i ka  ‘u‘uku a me ke koa loa. **b1)** ‘O Kauluakaha‘i, kona   makua kāne, **c)** no Kahikipapaialewa, he ‘āina i  Kahikinu‘u. **b2)** ‘O Pōka‘ī ka makuahine. **c)** He ali‘i  nui kona makua kāne no Kahikipapaialewa, a **b1)** he ‘ao‘ao akua kekahi ona.
llama-3.3-70B-Instruct_exl2_6.0bpw-maui_: Nāmakaokapāo'o was a very small child, and extremely strong when he was very young. There was no one like him from Hawai'i to Ni'ihau in terms of his small stature and bravery. His father was Kauluakaha'i, from Kahikipapaialewa, a place in Kahikinu'u. His mother was Pōka'ī. His father, Kauluakaha'i, was a high chief of Kahikipapaialewa and also partly divine.

**Paragraph 1:** 
• It is characteristic of Hawaiian narrative openings to introduce: 
  – **a)** The name and sometimes age or physical attributes of the main protagonist, in this case, **Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o** (the eyes of the pāo'o fish), emphasizing his extraordinary strength and small size, signifying a potential for greatness despite his youth.
  – **b1)** The paternal figure, **Ka-ulu-a-kaha'i** (the inspiration of Kaha'i), indicating a connection to heroic lineage and knowledge. Kaha'i, as referenced, is a historical figure associated with bravery and the introduction of breadfruit, suggesting that Nāmakaokapāo'o's lineage is marked by courage and resourcefulness.
  – **c)** The geographical or spiritual origin, **Kahiki-papa ia-lewa** (Kahiki stratum in the sky), and **Kahiki-nu'u** (Kahiki at the summit), which are foreign lands or perhaps spiritual realms, hinting at Nāmakaokapāo'o's genealogical connection to distant or divine origins.
  – **b2)** The maternal figure, **Pō-ka-'ī** (night falls upon the high chief), whose name suggests an association with the mystical or nocturnal, possibly indicating a balance to the paternal, heroic lineage with a more mystical or celestial influence.
• The combination of these elements sets the stage for a story that may explore themes of identity, power, and the balance between human and divine influences, which are common in Hawaiian mythology and reflective of the complex societal structures during the 'Ai Kapu era.
• The mention of **Kahikipapaialewa** and **Kahikinu'u** as places of origin for **Ka-ulu-a-kaha'i** points to a narrative that might engage with concepts of foreign influence, spiritual realms, and the intersection of the mundane with the divine, themes that were particularly relevant during periods of cultural and societal change, such as the transition out of the 'Ai Kapu system.
• The fact that Nāmakaokapāo'o's father is described as both a high chief and partly divine (**he 'ao'ao akua kekahi ona**) underscores the mythological context of the story, suggesting that Nāmakaokapāo'o's actions and destiny will be influenced by both mortal and divine forces, a common motif in Hawaiian stories where the protagonist's lineage and actions are deeply intertwined with the will of the gods and the balance of nature and society.
• The allegorical interpretation of Nāmakaokapāo'o's name, with **Nā-maka** potentially symbolizing wisdom, sight, or foresight, and **o-ka-pāo'o** referencing a fish known for its strength and perhaps the cyclical nature of life, suggests that the story may delve into themes of growth, transformation, and the balancing of opposites, echoing the broader philosophical and spiritual queries of Hawaiian tradition regarding the interconnectedness of all things and the pursuit of balance and harmony.
raw_response:
<translation>Nāmakaokapāo'o was a very small child, and extremely strong when he was very young. There was no one like him from Hawai'i to Ni'ihau in terms of his small stature and bravery. His father was Kauluakaha'i, from Kahikipapaialewa, a place in Kahikinu'u. His mother was Pōka'ī. His father, Kauluakaha'i, was a high chief of Kahikipapaialewa and also partly divine.</translation>

<commentary>**Paragraph 1:** 
• It is characteristic of Hawaiian narrative openings to introduce: 
  – **a)** The name and sometimes age or physical attributes of the main protagonist, in this case, **Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o** (the eyes of the pāo'o fish), emphasizing his extraordinary strength and small size, signifying a potential for greatness despite his youth.
  – **b1)** The paternal figure, **Ka-ulu-a-kaha'i** (the inspiration of Kaha'i), indicating a connection to heroic lineage and knowledge. Kaha'i, as referenced, is a historical figure associated with bravery and the introduction of breadfruit, suggesting that Nāmakaokapāo'o's lineage is marked by courage and resourcefulness.
  – **c)** The geographical or spiritual origin, **Kahiki-papa ia-lewa** (Kahiki stratum in the sky), and **Kahiki-nu'u** (Kahiki at the summit), which are foreign lands or perhaps spiritual realms, hinting at Nāmakaokapāo'o's genealogical connection to distant or divine origins.
  – **b2)** The maternal figure, **Pō-ka-'ī** (night falls upon the high chief), whose name suggests an association with the mystical or nocturnal, possibly indicating a balance to the paternal, heroic lineage with a more mystical or celestial influence.
• The combination of these elements sets the stage for a story that may explore themes of identity, power, and the balance between human and divine influences, which are common in Hawaiian mythology and reflective of the complex societal structures during the 'Ai Kapu era.
• The mention of **Kahikipapaialewa** and **Kahikinu'u** as places of origin for **Ka-ulu-a-kaha'i** points to a narrative that might engage with concepts of foreign influence, spiritual realms, and the intersection of the mundane with the divine, themes that were particularly relevant during periods of cultural and societal change, such as the transition out of the 'Ai Kapu system.
• The fact that Nāmakaokapāo'o's father is described as both a high chief and partly divine (**he 'ao'ao akua kekahi ona**) underscores the mythological context of the story, suggesting that Nāmakaokapāo'o's actions and destiny will be influenced by both mortal and divine forces, a common motif in Hawaiian stories where the protagonist's lineage and actions are deeply intertwined with the will of the gods and the balance of nature and society.
• The allegorical interpretation of Nāmakaokapāo'o's name, with **Nā-maka** potentially symbolizing wisdom, sight, or foresight, and **o-ka-pāo'o** referencing a fish known for its strength and perhaps the cyclical nature of life, suggests that the story may delve into themes of growth, transformation, and the balancing of opposites, echoing the broader philosophical and spiritual queries of Hawaiian tradition regarding the interconnectedness of all things and the pursuit of balance and harmony.</commentary>
reference_translation: Nāmakaokapāo‘o was a little boy and incredibly  strong when he was very young. There was no one  like him from Hawai‘i all the way to Ni‘ihau in his  small stature and bravery. Kauluakaha‘i was his  father from Kahikipapaialewa, a place in  Kahikinu‘u. Pōka‘ī was his mother. His father was a  high chief of Kahikipapaialewa, who was also part  god.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 1:**• It is very common in Hawaiian storytelling to open by  disclosing:  **a)** the name of the main protagonist/s, and   sometimes a description of their (aproximate) age  and/or physique/physical attributes;  **b)** the name of the parent/s, grandparent/s,  caregiver/s of the main protagonist/s, and sometimes  a description;  **c)** the name of the place the main protagonist/s grew  up or are living in at the time the story takes place;  • The main protagonists described in the first  paragraph are:  1\) Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o (m) (the eyes of the pāo‘o  fish): an incredibly strong, young boy, with no  comparison from Hawai‘i to Ni‘ihau for his small  stature and strength; 2\) Ka-ulu-a-kaha‘i (m) (the inspiration of Kaha‘i (Footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1977:385): Kaha‘i: “A hero who traveled to ‘Upolu, Samoa, and brought back breadfruit to Haki-pu‘u, Oahu (according to some versions) or to Pu‘u-loa, Kohala,  Hawaii (HM 97). He was born at ‘Ī-ao, Maui. He went to Kahiki to find his father, Hema, who had lost his eyes (HM 248). See Nā-maka-o-Kaha‘i.), Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s father; a high chief of Kahiki-papa ia-lewa (Kahiki stratum in the sky, likely a foreign  country), a place in Kahiki-nu‘u (Kahiki at the summit,  a foreign country); he is a demigod;  3\) Pō-ka-‘ī (f) (perhaps ʻnight falls upon the high  chief’): Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s mother; no further  description;
